comment: One of my cousins swears by Chivas for his daily dram and had me try it last day. I think it’s a quite decent blend, albeit a bit flat. I missed some dept and body.
Fruit forward, then sour and slightly smoky afterwards. Pushes to another sip.
The nose is apples and oak. It is VERY mild, sweet and easy to drink. Not complex at all. Bland, and good to introduce a wine drinker to scotch.
This is my go-to drink.  Any time and every time.  Smooth and delicious.
Friendly and light. On the nose I got honey and vanilla with oakiness. It tasted just like it smelled, butterscotch/vanilla with oak. The finish is warm and oaky. Good intro whisky on the cheap.
This one has me wondering why I'm liking poorly reviewed, blended scotches more than single malt, highly praised ones. great flavor and easy drinking.
Tobacco on the nose. Smoke, pepper, and... gravy?

A blend with a lot of Speyside character. Widely available and easy drinking. One negative is that the price has come up quite a bit over the years, at the same time several new options have come into the market. Not something I seek out, but when it crosses my path I have enjoyed its company. Cheers!

Initial: Smooth, mild

Twirl: Neutral, mild

After: Strong without the twirl

Overall: Average

Nose is fruit...apples and oak

Palate is small amount of smoke. Rich fruit cake

Finish is medium with more smoke

Vanilla, fudge, walnut towards the end.

Surprisingly good! Perfect for a  tumbler. Nicely balanced blend. Two thumps up!
smokey, woody. small amount of burn.
At the time of this review, this ranks as my number 1 worst whisky. Nothing enjoyable about this at all.

​
aromatic citrus alcohol nose. A decent blend - generic but pleasing, fairly smooth.
Drank this on allure of the seas.
Oaky, with a some vanilla bourbon character. Subtle peat smoke in the background.

A friend of mine really likes this one, so I had plenty chances to try it out. Definitely not a bad whisky, just not really my cup of tea.
Nice light-amber/gold colour. Smell is fresh, light and sweet. On the pallette some sweet tones: vanilla, brown sugar. With fruity tones: apple, pear. Decent all around whisky, but noting special. 2.9 out of 5

I won’t go into the tasting notes but this was my first foray into the world of scotch, went to a friends house to drink now and then and went looking in his liquor cabinet and pulled out a dusty box of Chivas 12. Being a bourbon man I had no idea what scotch was or what to expect. I poured a glass over some rocks and was pleasantly surprised! It wasn’t bad at all and I actually enjoyed it. Now having experienced other scotches and single malts I’ll say Chivas 12 is over priced for what it is and I’d spend a extra 10 bucks for a single malt. Just my 2 cents. Also I caught this on sale and decided to pick it up for old times sake so that’s says something else
Apple's right up front on the nose. Tastes like wood and then smoke with a bit of juice sweetness.
A decent budget blend, not much going on, but nice price

Sehr leicht zu trinken, Vanille und Toffee, leichter Nachbrand, nicht sehr stark - smooth

6/18 - Brasov

Surprisingly drinkable. Gentle blend that makes a good bae for
Many cocktails.
Delicious flavor, didn’t need ice but better with ice. Very smooth, had no problem finishing a bottle

Chivas Regal 12 years
Blended Scotch Whisky
Pale gold
Apple, vanilla, smoke
good starter, cheap and complex enough to appreciate
it's not bad but pretty unspectacular. sweet, tart, fruity. This would be good for mixed drinks for sure

Caramel apple, malted cereal, and a hint of marshmallow on the nose. The palate has apple juice and pepper, with some wood influences, all delivered kind of roughly, and nothing too complex. The finish has a little more pepper and peat, with some bitterness poking through. A whiff of tobacco from the empty glass. Slightly better than I remember, but pretty much the definition of "2 star scotch".
Loved this one, very smooth and refreshing
alcoholic, slight burning nostrils, apple, burnt sugar, sweetness, vanilla, apricot / peach finish 7.3
A bit of a harsh finish
Very good. Comparable to Jonnie Red.

Color: The color on this blended scotch is a nice straw color. The legs are thin, but hold on for a bit.

Nose: The nose starts off the show with red apple sweetness, honey, and a hint of briny peat. 

Taste: The palate is very pleasant with honey notes, a salted almond taste, with a note of vanilla as well.

Finish: The finish is a mellow crescendo that grows into a salty and slightly smoky apex and then fades into a shortish finale.

Thoughts: This for me was a really good blend. I'm really happy I picked this up and I think many people would enjoy this. It's really popular so it isn't hard to find! Could you get something better for the price? Probably. But this is good, and definitely worth trying. Sláinte!
Bit of smoke; better nose than taste which flattens our quick. Pretty simple. The type of scotch that makes you grasp where scotch could maybe go.
nice caramel and honey flavor. a touch of smoke. a hint of heat, but not bad for a blend.
Very strong. Lingering after Pete punch in the tongue

I’m a little surprised that I’ve made it this long without having tried such a big name in the world of whisky. It ticks the boxes for middle of the road, good-not-great, easy drinking blended scotch - fresh apple, vanilla, honey, light smoke, hung on a slightly oily, full-but-not-rich frame. I’m never going to crave this, but at a bar with limited options for the whisky aficionado, I’d take this over plenty of other similarly priced options.

Light and very pleasant on the nose. Pretty thin, but minimal burn, light smoke, and fruit. I'm tasting apple or something sweet. Sweet and smoke mostly. Tail is pleasant with lots of smoke in the back of the mouth. Everything is light and the balance is good, but pretty unassuming.
i find this to be a very approachable drink.  i can enjoy it any time.
Just kind of blah. Hint of apples. Very little peat
Fresh and aromatic smell.  Slight hint of apple.  Smooth beginning followed by medium heat and rougher ending.

The nose has a curious fusion of iodine and toasted nuts. The first sip adds a few wisps of smoke, and then an unexpected hint of berries emerges. The sweetness lingers, finishing with a much lighter flavor than the initial greeting would suggest.
Honey bomb, sweet finish. A touch of white grape and grass.  No rough edges, but short on complexity.

Decent blended Scotch.

On the nose, golden delicious apple slices.  On the palate, honey and charcoal ash with a hint of apple returning.  On the finish, slightly bitter and medicinal notes.
A great everyday blend. Easy drinking and smooth.
Apples, pears, salty nuts, and a whisper of smoke. Overall, a solid whisky. Twill be good for making cocktails, such as the Penicillin.
Thinner taste, somewhat better with fainter peatyness
This is sharp, and nearly undrinkable. Flavors of wet boot and degreasing solvent.
Starts sweet, finishes nutty with a slight hint of peat. Good daily drinker.
Nose is very pleasant, almost like white chocolate but it's very faint. The palate is pretty all round, mostly vanilla, some light peat, something sour too.

I can’t tell if I like this.  Part of me resents the thin dissipating finish and the lack of any bite or dusky smoke.  The other part of me finds  honey covered apples and a smooth pleasant quick drink.  Either way it seems like it shouldn’t take 12 years to make something fairly basic.
My go-to blend. Cheap, reasonably complex and smooth. Nothing distinct, just all around good.

Sharpe and tart. It has bite. back taste had smoke and leaving an after burn. 

rough 

no
Slight peat a little sweet honey highland park has more depth but this is pretty smooth just very plain in general though
Sweet, mild. Might consider a bottle

Straightforward, smooth, and pleasant
Gibbs St

Really solid, affordable blend that is light on the smell and taste. Good way to introduce others to scotch. I see that it is supposed to have peated Scotch in the blend, which I never tasted in the 50 mL sample I bought. I think this is better than similar priced Johnnie Walker and Dewar's, but I'd buy Monkey Shoulder over this. If you like lighter Scotch than try this Chivas Regal 12 because it is never offensive or difficult.
Light nose of caramelized sugar and taste of sweet cereal and finishes with a green mineral flavor such as with glenfiddich 12
One of the better entry level blends.

Very light nose, sweet
Light and smooth palate, light finish
Flavor is not entirely to my liking
Probably good for mixing or on fruit
50 mL sample, smooth but not very interesting
Just a drinkable blend, nothing special.
Vanilla and cane sugar on the nose. The taste adds some fudge to the pallet and finishes of with a hint of apple.

Seriously underwhelmed by what is supposed to be such a renowned whisky. That said I'm no expert and I don't drink blended whisky normally (single malt all the way it seems) so take this review with a massive grain of salt - basically a himalayan salt rock lamp . In summary the whisky felt bland and lifeless with a just a hint of sweetness. Absolutely unremarkable. Bought some coke (the dull kind) that I plan on drowning it with so my friends can drink it. Feels like heresy but it's just not for me and I personally can't find even a hint of character worth preserving. Really strange, must just be that my pallet is not adjusted correctly for blended whisky. I hope I revisit this whisky in a few years and discover that I've become more sensitive to its flavour.
Well balanced blend, not much brine or smoke, malted barley. Very popular in India.
This is not for me. It lacks body and complexity. Almost feels watered down.

Honeyed corn and oak and on the nose, quiet simple. Oak dominates on the pallet followed by hints of smoke and sweet nail polish ketone flavors. A medicinal antiseptic alcohol dominates after the initial impression. It lingers only briefly. 

Very simple but drinkable.

Хорош. Но не самый любимый.
Отличный классический бленд-скотч. 
Хорош, но без изгибов, хотя и придраться почти не к чему
Bought a 200ml at Total Wine near hotel.  Good stuff. Reminds me of Dewars White. A bit peaty but very smooth. Definitely will add to my collection.

Inoffensive and light.
Don’t know if it makes a difference, but it sat on my shelf for more than 10 years before opening.
It's unfortunate that the alcohol deprived it of any character. Only the warmth it produces after a sip feels good.
For the money, there isn’t a finer blended Scotch available.

This was my first scotch ever and where I became a scotch man. One more thing I get from my pop. It’s been price hiked to $38 a fifth here in OR, cant justify that. The gift packs that include a mini each of Extra and 18 yr for $35...ok sold. C’mon OLCC...get your shit together!
Not the best, but very nice.

Nose: apples and cola

Palate: apples, raisins, and cinnamon 

Finish: walnuts

Good value for a light and fruity blended scotch.
Solid scotch. Has good burn to it without water. Lacks extra flavor and complexity. Water makes it unspectacular.

Nose is a fresh, light floral fruit, apple, almost a hint of a citrus-like essence, light vanilla or toffee, cereal grain, oak spice. Taste is virtually the same but with the slightest hint of peat smoke and a quick moment of brine. A moment of sharpness, bitterness but goes away quick enough. Taste certainly does not last long or deliver a heavy punch though. Not complex. Ok but nothing to write home about. Almost weak overall and tastes slightly watered down at times. But for a blend, it’s not horrible.

Chivas Regal 12 has a gold appearance, with a slight green tint. Oddly, there are no alcohol legs. The nose is of sweet grain, with underlying peat and just a hint of smoke. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Chivas Regal 12 finishes dry. RJT
On nose light, citrusy. Nutty, coffee, bit of spice. Oaky, medium finish.
Young & rough, caramel, toffe, raisins pear, a bit smoky, oily, sweet and a bit sour, numbs the tongue...

Bargain for 20 quid but can still get a couple of single malts for this price. The Ardbeg and Jura journey when on offer are in the same price range and it would be hard to distinguish between the three which are all smokey. If you like mild smoke, this is as good as any

Good..one of my favorite blends with a age statement behind Johnnie Walker Black..vanilla, honey, butterscotch, toffee, caramel, heather, pear, apple, raisin, hazelnut, malt, grain, citrus and very shy peat..smooth..hardly a bite..definantly a speyside blend with a very very small hint of islay or island smokey whiskies added..
バランタインより大人しい？ でもスモーキー。美味しい。

Definitely needs to breathe. It has a light flavor, but the peat and smoke give it a kick that's overwhelming if it doesn't breathe. As it settles, I find it pretty easy to drink, especially when I use my full tongue instead of letting it set in the front of my mouth.

Nose: Pear, Honey, Dried fruit, Breakfast pastries 

Palate: Starts sweet, builds with a very mild burn and then a pleasant light smoke sets in

Finish: Somewhat oily and leaves a numbness feeling on the tongue along with that light smoke. 

Overall: Pleasant, reminds me of a smokier Glenmorangie that is complex yet delicate
Smooth, bland, consistent.  If Budweiser were a 12 year old Scotch, it would taste like this.
Vanilla, the taste was pleasant. The odour was mild.

I had this idea that I would try a few budget drams to see how my taste buds have evolved over the years. After 2 back-to-back budget blended Scotches (the other review will be up in a bit), I may throw in the towel and self-certify that my taste buds are calibrated and working correctly. Let’s get to the tasting notes for Chivas Regal 12 Year Old Blended Scotch. 

Nose: Thin and fruity, and not particularly complex. Green apple, Riesling, vanilla, and suggestions of old oak.  Hidden, dull fireplace smoke. 

Palate: Light, with a thin, watery mouthfeel. Vanilla, caramel, and cream with a dash of mild mannered salt. I think there’s some fruitiness to this but it’s lost in the apparent torrent of fire hydrant testing water used to cut this down to proof. 

Finish: Short and fairly one-note. Sweet, with faint oak tannins, bitterness, and tame spice. Over before you know it. 

I’m finding that few drams work at 40% ABV for me these days and this is no exception. Really unremarkable and boring. In hindsight, my rating appears a bit polite, but it has an age statement and doesn't have any obvious off-notes that completely turn me off from it. I think you could probably use this a mixer, but personally, I wouldn’t. 

2.25 ~ 68 ~ Nearly Regretting This
Хороший виски, при смешении в коктейле нет неприятных ощущений и похмелья тоже лёгкое

Sweet and smoky

Like eating a a smoked apple

Clearly blended. I couldn’t pin down a particular region it’s from. It’s light, a little smoky on the nose, had some citrus and floral notes. Overall just sweet. I would drink it, it’s far better than the Dewer’s White, but didn’t think it was anything special in a blind tasting.

It's unfortunate how many scotch snobs will look down their nose at Chivas Regal, or just blended scotches in general, as I think they offer a whisky with a lot of flavor and an age statement at a good price point. 

The nose is rich with aromas of apples, cola, and spice.

On the palate you get flowers, apples, raisins, and cinnamon.

Finish is smooth with flavors of grain whisky and walnuts.

While the flavor isn't complex, it is rich and enjoyable. Chivas 12 holds their own at a very competitive price point for scotches, and no matter how much I enjoy my single malts I hope I never become too much of a snob to turn down a glass of this enjoyable whisky.


Currently you can find this bottle in a gift pack with 50 ml bottles of Chivas 18 and Extra, which makes this an even better value and lets you try two other delicious blends.

It looks a pale amber, light gold.

I'm met first by scents of vanilla, toffee, and caramel; underneath, I find apple and citrus.

Frankly, the taste is pretty flat. There's a big punch of peat and spice up front, and not much to discover after that.

I'd choose it over Dewar's White Label, but it just seems like heat with no real depth.

Olfato: muito frutado, mel, baunilha, álcool de cereais, cítrico, floral leve e aroma adocicado. 

Paladar: baunilha, cítrico, adocicado e um pouco de mel. O álcool ainda é perceptível. Basicamente as mesmas características detectadas no aroma.

Finalização: curta, com retrogosto adocicado.

Impressões gerais: whisky simples, não turfado e bastante adocicado. Recomendado para coquetéis ou para degustação com gelo, mas não puro ou com água. Facilmente encontrado no Brasil, este blend pode agradar muitos bebedores iniciantes, porém é possível comprar um bom single malt por um preço similar.
Sweet vanilla and apples with some tart fruit notes. Hint of peat. Flavors disappear on the finish.
This bottle is from the early 1960s. Warm caramel and peat aroma. Taste matches aroma. Reminds of old books.

Color is like a light apple juice. Some distinctly floral notes once you work through the alcohol. Maybe some caramel too. Pleasantly oaky to start, but the alcohol overwhelms in the middle. The finish is a tad smoky. A little water allows you to taste some of the caramel. Overall not bad, but a bit bland.
Better than Dewars white, not as good as Johnnie black. Soil taste maybe is throwing me off.

Almost nothing on the nose. A bit of green apple.

Alcohol front and center on the pallate. A bit sweet, apples. Tiny amount of smoke.

Light smoke finish.

Fruity smell, apple and pear.
The taste follows the smell, apple juice, a hint of vanilla and cinnamon, then the mildest wisp of ashy peat.
Nutty and almost sweet. Aftertaste is smokey and salty.
Smooth, great smoky, slightly peaty finish. A good blended scotch.
No thanks. Sure...apples, pinch of salt, banana, malt are there....but bad. Best served with soda.
Definitely a lot of apples first time I’ve been able to definitively pick out a flavor in a whiskey

A whisky Best served with coke, a bit sweet, a bit vainilla... Gets a bit better after u drink it..

My first and (hope) last time tasting this

Pleasantly surprised with this slightly peated blend.  Fruity and smokey notes hit the nose early.  Apple and pear perhaps. Medium feel with a earthy peat , slight smoke and fruit. Short finish. Excellent. Thanks  Tang!
Hint of smokiness. Very light on the tongue
Spicy peppery. Sharp and woody. Typical college drink

On the nose a lot of cereal, vanilla, caramel and a hint of dried fruit, with a clear acidulous note that disappears with a little patience: overall sweet, but not really pleasant.
In the mouth things improve, the biscuit and sweet profile remains, softer than the smell, always accompanied by dried fruit and vanilla with an addition of plums and honey, together with a certain dryness on the background. Simple, linear, clean.
The finish is short, dry, with plums and dried fruit, vaguely acidic like the initial smell.
Nice spices. Just a little pest but not near as overwhelming as I thought it would be. Not as strong on initial taste, but stronger tail.
Caramel and mild peat. No burn whatsoever. Slightly salty. I really enjoy this one.
I got vanilla, oak, softness, smooth, then sharpness maybe peat on the finish.
Nothing too complex.  Taste of honey, walnuts, grass, & apples.  I do not taste any peat.  Something to drink so you don’t drink up all of your good stuff.
Better than I expected. Good for the price point.

Nose - sparkling apples, honey, dry spices, light cocoa, subtle smoke, moderate ethanol burn. 

Taste - green apple, toffee, light smoke, mild sherry flavors (raisin, chocolate, nondescript nuttiness), moderate ethanol burn, finishing reasonably long with herbal and nutty flavors.
Fortunately, bought this on clearance. Not detecting apple, peat, or really much of anything. Thin to the point of watery. Would not buy again.
Better than Dewars White Label or JW Black Label in my opinion. At $21/bottle I will happily sip this so I do not run through my good bottles.

Nose: light floral toffee. Vanilla, almond, with a sherry solvent note in the background. Light but overall pleasant.

Taste: praline, candied almond. Dark fruit and pear lurking in their somewhere. Finishes with dried dark fruit and a slight hint of sherried peat. No detectable hint of anything that screams “grain whisky” to me like in some blends, though I know they’re there.

Smooth, yes, but uninteresting.
Grain taste is strong. Decent malt taste and a bit of peat smoke. Similar to Teachers, more fruit than honey/caramel.
Strong honey taste bit of hazelnut with some vanilla and feels like some spray side
Strong honey flavour with some peat - good
Meh. Not much happening. Some honey and spice. Easy drinking but not worth buying.

I gave this Scotch a try after a friend recommended it to me as an entry-level Scotch. Well, I have to say I think his taste is different from mine. I have had only a few Scotches so I have fewer examples of good and bad liquids. Chivas Regal has a medicinal flavor maybe Iodine with a woody finish. It is not pleasant sipping it neat and ice helps it a little but nothing like a Bottled in Bond Bourbon. I am open to suggestions for other entry-level Scotches but this good for mixing at best but a serious drink is not me.
Fruitful taste and rich apple flavor
Mi gusta. It is easily a go to for a regular time.
Fruité,  goût très correct pour le prix : on est décidément pas dans un whisky bas de gamme. Mais on est pas dans le haut de gamme non plus. C'est très recommandable!
Meh. My first real basic intro to scotch.

On the nose is very light, you can perceive honey and a little vanilla, also a herbal note. Tons of apples and oranges. Cinnamon and clove. On the palate gets a little better, with honey vanilla and caramel and a strong pepper note as if you where eating a chilli.  Finish is soft with almost no kick. Spicy and fruity, amazing blend. 83 over 100.

Nose: Honey, floral, and a hint of vanilla. Very sweet. Slightly oaky as well.

Palate: Stronger than I thought but very smooth. Honey comes through a lot stronger with a seemingly tropical fruit taste as well. Floral is hidden but comes through just as it reaches the throat.

Finish: Oaky finish as I expected from the nose. But sweet and smooth to be sure. Lasting and enjoyable. I was expecting bitterness but I was pleasantly surprised. May be due to the fact that it was bottled in 2012 but I could be wrong.

Overall Thoughts: Good stuff. Easy to enjoy while putting your feet up and winding down. Wouldn’t say it’s top shelf or anything.

The flavor here is fuller then that of the Glenlivet 12, with definitely more bitter notes. The thing though is that there isn't a lot of subtlety going on here. The flavors aren't so much blended as pureed. It reminds me a bit of Maker's Mark, though it certainly still tastes like a scotch.
A timeless budget bottle. Love the vanilla and hints of Carmel.
